subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to use JUnit for multi-threaded code?
msgSnippet: I ll second that one, and add a variation on it: Test your multi-threaded code on an unusually slow system.  We developed a bunch of code that passed its unit
messageBody:
I'll second that one, and add a variation on it: Test your
multi-threaded code on an unusually slow system. We developed a bunch
of code that passed its unit tests just fine when run from our desktops
(fast single processor WinXP machines) and on our CruiseControl server
(fast dual processor Linux machine). But when we tried running it on a
quad processor PIII, stuff failed that we thought for months was safe
and sound.


Todd.

> Pat,
>
> A tip:
> Test your multi-threaded code on a computer with more than
> one processor. Some problems with multi-threading don't show
> up on a single cpu computer.
>
> Regards, Jan
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Pat Farrell <pfarrell@...> wrote:
> >
> > Java has been multi-threaded from the start, and Java 5 has native
> API
> > support for things like Barriers that used to be rolled by a
> toolsmith
> > reading the O'Reilly "Java Threads" book.
> >
> > It is not clear to me how to use JUnit to test multi-thread
> applications.
